trans-unit.source: Configuring ExpressRoute through an Exchange Provider
trans-unit.target: Configuring ExpressRoute through an Exchange Provider

trans-unit.source: This tutorial walks you through setting up ExpressRoute through exchange providers (EXPs).
trans-unit.target: This tutorial walks you through setting up ExpressRoute through exchange providers (EXPs).

trans-unit.source: Configure an ExpressRoute connection through an Exchange Provider
trans-unit.target: Configure an ExpressRoute connection through an Exchange Provider

trans-unit.source: To configure your ExpressRoute connection through an exchange provider, you’ll need to complete multiple steps in the proper order.
trans-unit.target: To configure your ExpressRoute connection through an exchange provider, you’ll need to complete multiple steps in the proper order.

trans-unit.source: These instructions will help you do the following:
trans-unit.target: These instructions will help you do the following:

trans-unit.source: Create and Manage ExpressRoute circuits
trans-unit.target: Create and Manage ExpressRoute circuits

trans-unit.source: Configure BGP peering for ExpressRoute circuits
trans-unit.target: Configure BGP peering for ExpressRoute circuits

trans-unit.source: Link a Virtual Network to the ExpressRoute circuit
trans-unit.target: Link a Virtual Network to the ExpressRoute circuit

trans-unit.source: Configuration prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Configuration prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Before you begin configuration, verify that you have met the following prerequisites:
trans-unit.target: Before you begin configuration, verify that you have met the following prerequisites:

trans-unit.source: Azure subscription
trans-unit.target: Azure subscription

trans-unit.source: Latest version of Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Latest version of Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: The following Virtual Network requirements:
trans-unit.target: The following Virtual Network requirements:

trans-unit.source: A set of IP address prefixes to be used in virtual networks in Azure
trans-unit.target: A set of IP address prefixes to be used in virtual networks in Azure

trans-unit.source: A set of IP prefixes on-premises (can contain public IP addresses)
trans-unit.target: A set of IP prefixes on-premises (can contain public IP addresses)

trans-unit.source: The Virtual Network Gateway must be created with a /28 subnet.
trans-unit.target: The Virtual Network Gateway must be created with a /28 subnet.

trans-unit.source: Additional set of IP prefixes (/28) that is outside of the virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Additional set of IP prefixes (/28) that is outside of the virtual network.

trans-unit.source: This will be used for configuring BGP peering.
trans-unit.target: This will be used for configuring BGP peering.

trans-unit.source: AS number for your network.
trans-unit.target: AS number for your network.

trans-unit.source: For more information about AS numbers, see [Autonomous System (AS) Numbers](http://www.iana.org/assignments/as-numbers/as-numbers.xhtml).
trans-unit.target: For more information about AS numbers, see [Autonomous System (AS) Numbers](http://www.iana.org/assignments/as-numbers/as-numbers.xhtml).

trans-unit.source: MD5 hash if you need an authenticated BGP session
trans-unit.target: MD5 hash if you need an authenticated BGP session

trans-unit.source: VLAN IDs on which traffic will be sent.
trans-unit.target: VLAN IDs on which traffic will be sent.

trans-unit.source: You will need 2 VLAN IDs for each circuit: one for virtual networks and the other for services hosted on public IP addresses.
trans-unit.target: You will need 2 VLAN IDs for each circuit: one for virtual networks and the other for services hosted on public IP addresses.

trans-unit.source: [Autonomous System (AS) Numbers](http://www.iana.org/assignments/as-numbers/as-numbers.xhtml) for your network.
trans-unit.target: [Autonomous System (AS) Numbers](http://www.iana.org/assignments/as-numbers/as-numbers.xhtml) for your network.

trans-unit.source: Two 1 Gbps / 10 Gbps cross-connects to the Exchange provider’s Ethernet Exchange.
trans-unit.target: Two 1 Gbps / 10 Gbps cross-connects to the Exchange provider’s Ethernet Exchange.

trans-unit.source: A pair of routers capable of supporting BGP for routing
trans-unit.target: A pair of routers capable of supporting BGP for routing

trans-unit.source: Deployment workflow
trans-unit.target: Deployment workflow

trans-unit.source: Configuring settings using PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Configuring settings using PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell is a powerful scripting environment that you can use to control and automate the deployment and management of your workloads in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell is a powerful scripting environment that you can use to control and automate the deployment and management of your workloads in Azure.

trans-unit.source: For more information please refer to the PowerShell documentation in [MSDN](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/jj156055.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information please refer to the PowerShell documentation in [MSDN](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/jj156055.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Import the PowerShell module for ExpressRoute.
trans-unit.target: Import the PowerShell module for ExpressRoute.

trans-unit.source: Get the list of providers, locations, and bandwidths supported.
trans-unit.target: Get the list of providers, locations, and bandwidths supported.

trans-unit.source: Before creating a circuit you will need a list of service providers, supported locations, and bandwidth options for each location.
trans-unit.target: Before creating a circuit you will need a list of service providers, supported locations, and bandwidth options for each location.

trans-unit.source: The following PowerShell cmdlet returns this information which you’ll use in later steps.
trans-unit.target: The following PowerShell cmdlet returns this information which you’ll use in later steps.

trans-unit.source: Create a Dedicated Circuit
trans-unit.target: Create a Dedicated Circuit

trans-unit.source: The example below shows how to create a 200 Mbps ExpressRoute circuit through Equinix Silicon Valley.
trans-unit.target: The example below shows how to create a 200 Mbps ExpressRoute circuit through Equinix Silicon Valley.

trans-unit.source: If you are using a different provider and different settings, substitute that information when making your request.
trans-unit.target: If you are using a different provider and different settings, substitute that information when making your request.

trans-unit.source: Below is an example request for a new service key:
trans-unit.target: Below is an example request for a new service key:

trans-unit.source: The response will be something similar to the example below:
trans-unit.target: The response will be something similar to the example below:

trans-unit.source: You can retrieve this information at any time using the Get-AzureCircuit cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can retrieve this information at any time using the Get-AzureCircuit cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Making the call without any parameters will list all circuits.
trans-unit.target: Making the call without any parameters will list all circuits.

trans-unit.source: Your Service Key will be listed in the ServiceKey field.
trans-unit.target: Your Service Key will be listed in the ServiceKey field.

trans-unit.source: Send the Service Key to your exchange provider.
trans-unit.target: Send the Service Key to your exchange provider.

trans-unit.source: Your exchange provider will use the Service Key to enable their end of the connection.
trans-unit.target: Your exchange provider will use the Service Key to enable their end of the connection.

trans-unit.source: You will have to provide the connectivity provider with additional information to enable connectivity.
trans-unit.target: You will have to provide the connectivity provider with additional information to enable connectivity.

trans-unit.source: Periodically check the status and the state of the circuit key.
trans-unit.target: Periodically check the status and the state of the circuit key.

trans-unit.source: This will allow you to know when your provider has enabled your circuit.
trans-unit.target: This will allow you to know when your provider has enabled your circuit.

trans-unit.source: Once the circuit has been enabled, the *ServiceProviderProvisioningState* will display as *Provisioned* as shown in the example below.
trans-unit.target: Once the circuit has been enabled, the *ServiceProviderProvisioningState* will display as *Provisioned* as shown in the example below.

trans-unit.source: Configure routing for virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Configure routing for virtual network.

trans-unit.source: We use BGP sessions to exchange routes and also make sure that we have high availability.
trans-unit.target: We use BGP sessions to exchange routes and also make sure that we have high availability.

trans-unit.source: Use the example below to create a BGP session for your circuit.
trans-unit.target: Use the example below to create a BGP session for your circuit.

trans-unit.source: Substitute your own values when creating your session.
trans-unit.target: Substitute your own values when creating your session.

trans-unit.source: You can get routing information for a circuit using Get-AzureBGPPeering by providing the service key.
trans-unit.target: You can get routing information for a circuit using Get-AzureBGPPeering by providing the service key.

trans-unit.source: You can also update the BGP settings using Set-AzureBGPPeering.
trans-unit.target: You can also update the BGP settings using Set-AzureBGPPeering.

trans-unit.source: The BGP session will not come up when this command is run.
trans-unit.target: The BGP session will not come up when this command is run.

trans-unit.source: The circuit must be linked with at least one VNet to get the BGP session up.
trans-unit.target: The circuit must be linked with at least one VNet to get the BGP session up.

trans-unit.source: The response below will provide you with the information that you will need for the next steps.
trans-unit.target: The response below will provide you with the information that you will need for the next steps.

trans-unit.source: Use the peer ASN to configure BGP on your router’s VRFs.
trans-unit.target: Use the peer ASN to configure BGP on your router’s VRFs.

trans-unit.source: Configure routing for services hosted on public IP addresses.
trans-unit.target: Configure routing for services hosted on public IP addresses.

trans-unit.source: We use BGP sessions to exchange routes and also make sure that we have high availability.
trans-unit.target: We use BGP sessions to exchange routes and also make sure that we have high availability.

trans-unit.source: Use the example below to create a BGP session for your circuit.
trans-unit.target: Use the example below to create a BGP session for your circuit.

trans-unit.source: Substitute your own values when creating your session.
trans-unit.target: Substitute your own values when creating your session.

trans-unit.source: You can get routing information for a circuit using Get-AzureBGPPeering by providing the service key.
trans-unit.target: You can get routing information for a circuit using Get-AzureBGPPeering by providing the service key.

trans-unit.source: You can also update the BGP settings using Set-AzureBGPPeering.
trans-unit.target: You can also update the BGP settings using Set-AzureBGPPeering.

trans-unit.source: The BGP session will not come up when this command is run.
trans-unit.target: The BGP session will not come up when this command is run.

trans-unit.source: The circuit must be linked with at least one VNet to get the BGP session up.
trans-unit.target: The circuit must be linked with at least one VNet to get the BGP session up.

trans-unit.source: The response below will provide you with the information that you will need for the next steps.
trans-unit.target: The response below will provide you with the information that you will need for the next steps.

trans-unit.source: Use the peer ASN to configure BGP on your router’s VRFs.
trans-unit.target: Use the peer ASN to configure BGP on your router’s VRFs.

trans-unit.source: Configure your virtual network and gateway.
trans-unit.target: Configure your virtual network and gateway.

trans-unit.source: See [Configure a Virtual Network and Gateway for ExpressRoute](expressroute-configuring-vnet-gateway.md).
trans-unit.target: See [Configure a Virtual Network and Gateway for ExpressRoute](expressroute-configuring-vnet-gateway.md).

trans-unit.source: Note that the gateway subnet must be /28 in order to work with an ExpressRoute connection.
trans-unit.target: Note that the gateway subnet must be /28 in order to work with an ExpressRoute connection.

trans-unit.source: Link your network to a circuit.
trans-unit.target: Link your network to a circuit.

trans-unit.source: Proceed with the following instructions only after you have confirmed that your circuit has moved to the following state and status:
trans-unit.target: Proceed with the following instructions only after you have confirmed that your circuit has moved to the following state and status:

trans-unit.source: ServiceProviderProvisioningState: Provisioned
trans-unit.target: ServiceProviderProvisioningState: Provisioned

trans-unit.source: Status: Enabled
trans-unit.target: Status: Enabled

trans-unit.source: Next Steps
trans-unit.target: Next Steps

trans-unit.source: For more information about ExpressRoute, see the [ExpressRoute FAQ](expressroute-faqs.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about ExpressRoute, see the [ExpressRoute FAQ](expressroute-faqs.md).

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
